Hierarchical Bayesian Model

Our Study Group

2025-05-22

Source: vignettes/articles/Hierarchical_Bayesian_Model.qmd

Big Picture: What Are We Modeling?

We are modeling how antibody levels change over time in response to infection, using data from multiple individuals and multiple biomarkers (10 antigen-isotype combinations, so ( j = 1, 2, ‚Ä¶, 10 )).

We want to:

  • Understand the average pattern for each biomarker
  • Allow each person‚Äôs response to vary
  • Share information across individuals to improve estimates

This is a perfect use case for a hierarchical Bayesian model.

Step 1: Individual-Level Parameters (Subject-Level)

Each person (ii), for biomarker (jj), has their own unique set of parameters:

Œ∏ij=[y0,ijb0,ijŒºb,ijŒºy,ijŒ≥ijŒ±ijœÅij] \theta_{ij} = \begin{bmatrix} y_{0,ij} \\ b_{0,ij} \\ \mu_{b,ij} \\ \mu_{y,ij} \\ \gamma_{ij} \\ \alpha_{ij} \\ \rho_{ij} \end{bmatrix}

These describe the antibody curve for person ( ii ) and biomarker ( jj ): the starting level, how fast it rises, peaks, and decays.

Step 2: Population-Level Parameters (Per Biomarker jj)

Now we summarize how people typically behave for each biomarker:

Œºj=population mean vector for biomarker j \mu_j = \text{population mean vector for biomarker } j

This means:

  • For biomarker ( jj ), we believe the true average antibody trajectory is governed by parameters ( Œºj\mu_j ).

  • But we don‚Äôt know ( Œºj\mu_j ) ‚Äî so we estimate it using data across all individuals.

Step 3: Hierarchical Modeling Structure

We assume each individual‚Äôs parameter vector Œ∏ij\theta_{ij} is drawn from a multivariate normal distribution:

Œ∏ij‚àºùí©(Œºj,Œ£j) \theta_{ij} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_j, \Sigma_j)

  • Œºj\mu_j : the population-level mean for biomarker ( jj )
  • Œ£j\Sigma_j : j√ójj√ój covariance matrix describing how the parameters co-vary

This is where the ‚Äúborrowing strength‚Äù happens. Even if someone has sparse data, we can still make good inferences by using the group-level pattern.

Step 4: Priors on Population Means ‚Äî ‚ÄúHyperpriors‚Äù

But wait ‚Äî since we are Bayesian, so we also need a prior belief about Œºj\mu_j :

Œºj‚àºùí©(Œºhyp,j,Œ©hyp,j) \mu_j \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_{\text{hyp},j}, \Omega_{\text{hyp},j})

Where:

  • Œºhyp,j\mu_{\text{hyp},j} : prior guess for the population mean (e.g., a vector of zeros ))
  • Œ©hyp,j\Omega_{\text{hyp},j} : uncertainty about that guess (e.g., 100‚ãÖI7100 \cdot I_7 for weakly informative prior)

This is a hyperprior, because it‚Äôs a prior on a prior-level parameter.

Step 5: Priors on Covariance ‚Äî ‚ÄúPriors on Variability‚Äù

We also don‚Äôt know how much individual parameters vary. So we assign a Wishart prior to the inverse covariance matrix:

Œ£j‚àí1‚àºùí≤(Œ©j,ŒΩj) \Sigma_j^{-1} \sim \mathcal{W}(\Omega_j, \nu_j)

  • Œ©j\Omega_j : prior scale matrix (small variance across parameters, often 0.1‚ãÖI70.1 \cdot I_7)
  • ŒΩj\nu_j : degrees of freedom

This tells the model how much we expect individuals to vary from the average for biomarker jj.

Step 6: Measurement Error Model

Our observations are noisy! So we model the observed log-antibody levels log(yobs,ij)log(y_{obs,ij}) like this:

log(yobs,ij)‚àºùí©(log(ypred,ij),œÑj‚àí1) \log(y_{\text{obs},ij}) \sim \mathcal{N}(\log(y_{\text{pred},ij}), \tau_j^{-1})

Where œÑj‚àºGamma(aj,bj)\tau_j \sim \text{Gamma}(a_j, b_j) is a prior on measurement precision for biomarker jj.

Step 7: Putting It All Together

The model is built hierarchically across five conceptual levels:

  1. Observed data: log antibody concentrations from serum samples
  2. Individual-level parameters: specific antibody dynamics for each subject-biomarker pair
  3. Population-level means: average antibody parameters for each biomarker
  4. Hyperpriors on means: our belief about the likely range of population means
  5. Priors on variability: our belief about individual variation around those means

This structure lets us account for uncertainty at every level, while borrowing strength across subjects and biomarkers.

Summary of the Hierarchy

Let‚Äôs stack it up top-down:

  1. Top Level:

    • For each biomarker jj, the true mean antibody trajectory parameters Œºj\mu_j come from a prior ùí©(Œºhyp,j,Œ©hyp,j)\mathcal{N}(\mu_{\text{hyp},j}, \Omega_{\text{hyp},j})

  2. Middle Level:

    • For each person ii, their parameters Œ∏ij‚àºùí©(Œºj,Œ£j)\theta_{ij} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_j, \Sigma_j)

  3. Bottom Level:

    • Their actual observed antibody levels are noisy measurements of predictions from Œ∏ij\theta_{ij}

RECAP: Where We Are

Step 3: Modeling Individuals

We say:

Œ∏ij‚àºùí©(Œºj,Œ£j) \theta_{ij} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_j, \Sigma_j)

This means:

  • For biomarker jj, each subject ii has their own parameter vector Œ∏ij\theta_{ij}
  • These vectors come from a Normal distribution centered at Œºj\mu_j (the population mean for that biomarker)
  • Œ£j\Sigma_j is the covariance matrix capturing variation across individuals for that biomarker

But here‚Äôs the catch: we don‚Äôt know Œºj\mu_j or Œ£j\Sigma_j yet.

So How Do We Handle the Unknowns?

In Bayesian modeling, we treat unknowns as random variables too. So instead of fixing Œºj\mu_j and Œ£j\Sigma_j, we say:

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs estimate them, but we‚Äôll put a prior belief on them to guide the learning.‚Äù

This brings us to:

Step 4: Priors on Œºj\mu_j

Œºj‚àºùí©(Œºhyp,j,Œ©hyp,j) \mu_j \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_{\text{hyp},j}, \Omega_{\text{hyp},j})

Explanation:

  • Œºj\mu_j: unknown population-level mean of the parameters for biomarker jj
  • We say:

‚ÄúWe believe Œºj\mu_j comes from another normal distribution‚Äù

  • Centered at Œºhyp,j\mu_{\text{hyp},j} ‚Äî a guess for what the mean might be

  • With spread Œ©hyp,j\Omega_{\text{hyp},j} ‚Äî how confident we are in that guess

If we want to be very flexible, we make this prior weakly informative:

  • Set Œºhyp,j=0\mu_{\text{hyp},j} = 0
  • Set Œ©hyp,j=100‚ãÖI7\Omega_{\text{hyp},j} = 100 \cdot I_7, where I7I_7 is the identity matrix (saying we are uncertain)

This is a prior on a population-level parameter ‚Äî a ‚Äúhyperprior‚Äù.

Step 5: Priors on Œ£j\Sigma_j

We also don‚Äôt know how much individual parameters vary, so we say:

Œ£j‚àí1‚àºùí≤(Œ©j,ŒΩj) \Sigma_j^{-1} \sim \mathcal{W}(\Omega_j, \nu_j)

This is a Wishart prior on the precision matrix (inverse of covariance). Why?

  • In multivariate stats, it‚Äôs common to use the Wishart distribution as a prior for covariance matrices
  • Œ©j\Omega_j: the scale (like the average covariance we expect)
  • ŒΩj\nu_j: degrees of freedom (how confident we are)

If we want to be uninformative, we might say:

  • Œ©j=0.1‚ãÖI7\Omega_j = 0.1 \cdot I_7
  • ŒΩj=8\nu_j = 8

That allows a wide range of possible covariance matrices.

Summary of Why Priors Show Up

Priors appear at step 4 and 5 because we are now modeling the parameters themselves.

In Bayesian statistics:

  • Every unknown quantity is treated as a random variable
  • Every random variable must have a probability distribution
  • That‚Äôs what priors are

They let us encode our beliefs, and importantly, they let us regularize the model so it doesn‚Äôt overfit sparse or noisy data.
